summary: On May 12, 2016, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California entered a final judgment against Gap, Inc. ("Gap"), a California-based apparel and accessories company, that permanently enjoins it from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Rule 17(b) thereunder, and orders it to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Los Angeles, charges Gap with violating the anti-fraud provision of the federal securities laws and seeks injunctive relief, a civil penalty, and an officer-and-director bar.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Gap has consented to the entry of a judgment permanently enjoining it from future violations of the charged provisions.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Central District of New York today announced criminal charges against Gap.  On November 29, 2017, the SEC filed an amended complaint against Gap that alleges that it violated the federal registration provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(e) ofÂ the Securities Act, and Section 10(b)(5) and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The SEC seeks a permanent injunction against future violations and a conduct-based injunction.  According to the SEC’s complaint, the court found that Gap had a duty to disclose to consumers that factory store items were not sold in traditional Gap stores and that it had exclusive knowledge of the sales history of factory store goods.  It also found that, in using the Gap and Banana Republic brand names on factory store clothing labels, Gap failed to disclose that the factory store merchandise was of lesser quality than those sold at retail stores.  Further, the complaint alleges that Gap violated Section 17 (a)(1) and (3) the registration provision of Section 5 of theÂ Federal Trade Commission, and that Gap is liable for violations of Sections 13(a)(2) and 13(c).  The complaint also alleges that, as alleged in the SEC complaint, Gap violated Sections 17 (b)(2)(A), (3), and (4) of The Securities Act and Sections 10(d) and 14(e)(1)(B) and 15e-3 of the Exchange Act and Rules 12b-20, 13a-1, 13b-11, and 14e-13 thereunder; that Gap has a duty of disclosure under Section 5 under the UCL and Rules 10d-1 and 13e-14 thereunder under the SEC registration provisions; that it has an obligation to
